questionListItems.title: What are the safety regulations in place for toddlers onboard?

answer.body:
For the safety of toddlers, during taxi, take off and landing as well as and turbulent weather:

  • Toddlers below the age of two are to be held by an adult who is occupying a seat and who has the child securely restrained with a child restraint device; and

  • Toddlers aged two years and above are to be properly secured in their seats by the seat belt provided for the seat or is occupying a seat equipped with an approved child restraint system.

Travellers are advised to check with their airline if they require information on the types of appropriate child restraint systems approved to be used on board for toddlers of both age groups.

More information can be found under Regulation 51 of Air Navigation Regulation - 91 and Regulation 87 of Air Navigation Regulation - 121.

For additional guidance, please refer to Advisory Circular AC 121-6-3 - Acceptable Child Restraint Devices.

questionListItems.title: Are passenger safety briefings similar for all aircraft types?

answer.body:
Passenger safety briefings may vary, depending on the aircraft type*. It is therefore important to pay attention to the passenger safety briefing for every flight. More information can be found here.

*Please refer to Regulation 20 of Air Navigation Regulation - 91, and Regulation 18 of Air Navigation Regulation - 121. For additional guidance, refer to Advisory Circular - AC 121-1-1.

questionListItems.title: Am I allowed to place luggage exceeding 10kg in the overhead compartment (for budget airlines)?

answer.body:
The total weight of the cabin luggage within each overhead compartment must not exceed the weight limit of the compartment. CAAS requires airlines to ensure that loading instructions and training be provided to its staff to ensure that the weight limitations of the overhead compartments are adhered to.

Airlines have the discretion to set the weight limit of hand luggage that can be carried into the cabin by each passenger as long as they meet CAAS’s safety requirements. Passengers should therefore check with their airlines on the weight limit of their hand luggage.

For more information, please refer to Regulation 16 of Air Navigation Regulation - 91 and Regulation 9 of Air Navigation Regulation – 121. For additional guidance, refer to Advisory Circular AC121-1-1.

questionListItems.title: Are airlines allowed to leave the seats at overwing emergency exits/self-help exits empty?

answer.body:
Over-wing emergency exits, also referred to as self-help exits, may not be manned by cabin crew. Airlines have the discretion to manage the seating of their passengers at such exits if they have established procedures to ensure expeditious evacuation if required. Passengers seated at these exits may be required to operate the exits and are required to be briefed on the operation of these exits before take-off and if required, before landing.

For more information, please refer to Regulation 17 and Regulation 18 of Air Navigation Regulation - 121. For additional guidance, refer to Advisory Circular - AC 121-1-1.

questionListItems.title: What are self-help exits and who can be allocated these seats?

answer.body:
Some aircraft are equipped with emergency exits located near the wings of the aircraft, also known as overwing emergency exits or self-help exits. In line with international best practice, these exits are not required to be manned by crew. However, these exits may be operated by passengers seated adjacent to these exits. Only passengers who are capable of operating and willing to assist with operating the exit in the event of an emergency can be allocated the seats at these exits. Such passengers will receive a safety briefing before take-off on the emergency procedures to operate the exits.

For more information, please refer to Regulation 17 and Regulation 18 of Air Navigation Regulation - 121. For additional guidance, refer to Advisory Circular - AC 121-1-1.

questionListItems.title: What items can be hand carried on board an aircraft?

answer.body:
Examples of common items that can be hand carried in board an aircraft are:

  • Portable medical and electronic devices such as cameras, mobile phones, laptops and tablets.

  • Spare lithium batteries (including power banks) for electronic devices. Passengers are not allowed to carry more than two and they must be individually protected to prevent short circuits.

  • Toiletries and cosmetics such as hair sprays, perfumes and medicines containing aerosols, alcohol or liquids, provided that each container does not exceed 100ml and the total quantity in all the containers does not exceed 1 litre. All the containers should be placed in a transparent re-sealable plastic bag which must be completely sealed.

  • Alcoholic beverages in retail packaging and which do not exceed 70% alcohol by volume.

More information can be found here.

questionListItems.title: Why are there differing conditions for the usage of Portable Electronic Devices (PEDs) across different airlines?

answer.body:
Passengers are permitted to use PEDs on board aircraft, subject to the prevailing regulations*. Airlines may additionally apply a more restrictive policy on the use of PEDs and the permissible times, conditions and limitations of use.

Information on airlines’ PED policies may be found on their websites, in their safety information cards and/or in-flight magazines. Passengers are advised to pay attention to in-flight announcements for instructions in the use of PEDs, and to also check with their airlines before travelling if in doubt.

The usage of PEDs onboard is generally safe on most aircraft types as verified by aircraft and PED manufacturers who have performed analyses on their usage. Before airlines permit the usage of PEDs, they must confirm that their aircraft can safely handle interference from PEDs.

More information on the use of PEDs can also be found here.

*Please refer to Regulations 10, 11 & 13 of Air Navigation Regulation 121. For additional guidance, refer to the relevant Advisory circular here.

questionListItems.title: What requirements must a technical staff satisfy before he/she can be nominated as certifying staff of a Singapore Airworthiness Regulation-Part 145 (SAR-145) Approved Maintenance Organisation?

answer.body:
Please refer to the following Advisory Circulars for the requirements for nominated certifying staff:

a) Advisory Circular AC 145-2 Initial Qualification Requirements for Certifying Staff.
b) Advisory Circular AC 145-8 Authorisation of Line Maintenance Certifying Staff.
c) Advisory Circular AC 66-9 Acceptance of Foreign Aircraft Maintenance Licenses for SAR-145 Maintenance Facilities outside Singapore.

The Advisory Circulars can be obtained here.

questionListItems.title: In applying for a Singapore Airworthiness Regulation-Part 145 (SAR-145) Maintenance Organisation Approval, the organisation must nominate a Quality Manager. What qualifications must the Quality Manager possess?

answer.body:
A Quality Manager should possess at least the following qualifications:



a) Possess at least 2 years’ experience in quality assurance in a related aviation environment,

b) Pass the CAAS Air Legislation examination paper,

c) Hold an aircraft maintenance engineer’s license (or its equivalent) recognised by CAAS, for organisation maintaining aircraft, and

d) Preferably have a relevant degree or diploma in a relevant discipline.

Note: For overseas organisations, CAAS typically accepts the nomination of a Quality Manager approved by the National Aviation Authority.

questionListItems.title: What do I need to apply for a Singapore Airworthiness Requirement-Part 145 (SAR-145) Maintenance Organisation Approval?

answer.body: An applicant, who intends to apply for a SAR-145 Maintenance Organisation Approval, needs to show cause to CAAS by producing satisfactory grounds for application of such approval. Satisfactory grounds include a Letter of Intent from a Singapore air operator or an existing SAR-145 Approved Maintenance Organisation. Once the applicant is assessed to be eligible, the applicant can proceed to apply for a SAR-145 Maintenance Organisation Approval formally through CAAS' Enterprise Safety Oversight System (eSOMS) portal.

questionListItems.title: Where can I find more information on the Working Arrangement on Airworthiness Certification (WA-AC) between the European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) and CAAS?

answer.body: The WA-AC establishes a reciprocal arrangement between the two organisations to validate and accept each other’s design certifications and approvals of aircraft parts, aircraft modifications and repairs. In addition, Design Organisation Approval (DOA) holders will no longer need to hold duplicate CAAS and EASA Approvals to operate in both Singapore and Europe. The number of regulatory inspections will be reduced, resulting in time and cost savings for the aviation industry on both sides. Air operators and other industry stakeholders from both Europe and Singapore will benefit from this arrangement. More information on the WA-AC can be found in Advisory Circular AC 21-5(0).

questionListItems.title: How do I apply for a design approval such as Supplemental Type Certificate for Aircraft Design (STC), Singapore Technical Standard Order Approval (STSO), Repair Design Approval (RDA) or minor modification?

answer.body: You would need to hold a SAR-21 Design Organisation Approval (DOA) before applying for a STC, STSO, RDA or minor modification. Application for design approvals for STSO may be performed through CAAS’ Enterprise Safety Oversight System (eSOMS) portal, while those for STC, RDA or minor modifications will be processed directly by CAAS officers assigned to the organisation.

questionListItems.title: What is the difference between a major and minor modification or repair?

answer.body:
A major modification or repair is one that might appreciably affect weight, balance, structural strength, performance, power plant operation, flight characteristics or other qualities affecting airworthiness; or one that is not done according to accepted practices or elementary operations. All other modifications or repairs are categorised as "minor".

Additional information can be found in Advisory Circular AC21-1(3), including the detailed criteria for the classification of major and minor modification or repair in Appendix A.

questionListItems.title: What are the requirements to be nominated as a certifying staff of a Singapore Airworthiness Regulation-Part 21 (SAR-21) Approved Production Organisation?

answer.body:
The Certifying Staff should meet the following requirements:


(a) possess appropriate qualifications and knowledge and at least one year of recent quality control experience in a related aviation field;

 

(b) possess knowledge of the appropriate Singapore aviation legislation. Knowledge of aviation legislation may be demonstrated by passing the CAAS' examination on Airworthiness Administration (L11 or L12) or Aviation Legislation (M10) or by attending L11 or M10 courses conducted by an approved maintenance training organisation;

 

(c) hold a position in the quality department of the organisation.

questionListItems.title: What are the requirements to be nominated as design signatory of a Singapore Airworthiness Regulation-Part 21 (SAR-21) Approved Design Organisation?

answer.body:
The Design Signatory should meet the following requirements:


(a) possess professional and technical qualifications, and knowledge appropriate for the activity; and at least 5 years of recent engineering experience (one year of this experience should be on engineering work on civil aircraft and in a field similar to that for which the approval is held);

 

(b) possess knowledge of the appropriate Singapore aviation legislation and airworthiness design standards as listed in Singapore Airworthiness Requirements, Part 21 (SAR-21) Subpart I. Knowledge of aviation legislation may be demonstrated by passing the CAAS' examination papers on Airworthiness Administration (L11), or Aviation Legislation (M10) or by attending L11 or M10 courses conducted by an approved maintenance training organisation;

 

(c) hold a position of sufficient authority in the organisation to ensure adequate control over designs within the relevant area of responsibility.
